We did have some profits budgeted, but we did the budget as Mike said back in March, April last year. So we had assumed some property profits.

To be accurate, we actually had some properties on the market about the time, and from memory, Ralph, we got one just away before, just before yields went the wrong way, and thereafter that we just basically took them off the marketplace. So we actually had identified those products that we wanted to market this year, but we're just going to delay it, no point in giving them away because they're good assets.
The profits in that would have been in your previous guidance but now they wouldn't be, but your guidance is still the same, is that right?
Yeah, that's correct. Filled the hole, David, yes.

Okay. And Mike, there was one comment, I think Tom said it, but I wanted, and a lot of it's on your increased capital expend, but I think Tom said that this year, you free cash flow wasn't going to quite cover your dividend payments, which is obviously 2 billion bucks worth of CapEx does that to you. I'm just interested as to how long you're likely to let that continue, or how long will it be until we can expect the free cash to really start spitting out of the company rather than significant reinvestment in capital?
I would expect the reinvestment to continue through FY10, David.
Yeah.
And I think FY11 will probably slowdown.
And Tom, you'd be expecting that your free cash flow will still be a bit shy of your divvy.

At this stage. I mean, given the uncertainty of the environment we are in, but we do really want to focus on spending CapEx in our growth areas, you know, new stores, refurbs , the new business area – new business areas that we're focusing on. So we're happy to pull it back on this stay-in-business type CapEx which doesn't really matter if you do this year, next year or the year after, but on those growth – those growth investments, we really want to keep focusing on those.

And just on your funds employed having increased by 1.4 billion. I mean you probably answered this question, I mean if you have, then don't worry- you have increased your funds employed by 1.4 billion, so you're going very hard. Are there any signs that you might just want to pull back a smidgen given that we're going into very uncertain economic times?
Not as yet. Part of that funds employed was impacted by the period-end close issue that I spoke about.
Okay.
Okay. So that's probably added 300 million plus to that number.
I think...

But we are – we don't do this blindly, David- we review where the trading businesses are on a weekly basis, and we make those decisions. So we are not going to be silly in this. But right now, as Michael said, the businesses are tracking very well. So at this point we just continue with our plan.

Just quickly David on the – we do check runs month-end and weekly runs, and previous half finished on December 30. So it sort of missed end of month, and of course this year is January 4. So it got the end of month and it got the weekly run. So there's about, between the two over-inflated last year and sort of a hit this year. Combined, it's just short of $700 million in the turnaround. So that's why the normalized, or the pro-forma's there, to reflect the fact that we got a free kick last year, which Tom did bring to the attention of this room and this year the alternative has happened.

Yeah. And just very finally, on consumer electronics, I know that that's been done to death, but just on your cost of doing business; I think best in-class in Australia at the moment is about 13 or 14%. You're obviously a way away from that.
Wonderful opportunity, absolutely. I would suggest that's an opportunity for us. We are not going to get there overnight, but it's a wonderful target to set your sail for, isn't it?

Well, I just wonder with the new store format, the ones that I looked at, I am just wondering whether you can get your cost doing business down to that level, and obviously that must be your plan, is it?

Well, one of the great things about this is that they are very interactive. So customers can actually get a lot more information about the product and touch and feel, without us having to go and open a locked cabinet to get out something, and then talk them through it. So, there is a lot of, more of self-service, and self understanding of product, than the present model.
Thanks guys.
No more? Is there is any final question here in the room at all?

Once again, thank you very much for your attendance here today, and I look forward to well-balanced reports coming out, with recommendations that are showing confidence in Australian retailing. Thank you.
